The instrument of the immortals: Steinway Welte Grand The instrument of the immortals Steinway Welte Grand Steinway & Sons The Tatler London 1922 The Tatler No. 1119, Dec 6 1922 XIX English
The Instrument of the Immortals The slogan was originally invented by Raymond Rubicam in 1919, who referred to the long-lasting history of Steinway pianos (Julian Watkins, *The 100 Greatest Advertisements 1852–1958*, p. 45). Nevertheless, the "immortality" theme is analysed here, since the slogan gets reinterpreted by its context.
Steinway Welte Grand The Welte-Mignon, which reproduces absolutely the Artists' original renderings , retains its position amongst the World's foremost and greatest reproducing instru- ments. The Steinway Welte is made also as a self-contained upright piano. Welte cabi- nets when desired can be supplied separately for at- tachment to any pianoforte. Renderings by:
Paderewski, Pachmann, Busoni, Josef Hofmann, Mark Hambourg, Puish-noff, Fanny Davies, d'Al-bert , Bloomfield-Zeisler, Carreño, Debussy , Doh-nányi , Grieg, Grünfeld Lamond, Leschetitzky, Lhevinne, Pugno, Saint-Saens, Samaroff, Sapellni-koff, Scharwenka, Schelling, Strauss, Schumann, etc.
Until the Welte-Mignon made its appearance all the piano-playing 'instruments aimed at making the interpretation of a piece of music mechanically correct; the Welte-Mignon caught the great masters in the act of playing, and fixed their style for ever.
Steinway & Sons
Steinway Hall 15 & 17, Lower Seymour Street, London S.W.1
Steinway & Sons and their Agents make it conveniently possible for music lovers to own a Steinwa. Pianos of other makes takes taken in exchange. Write for particulars. Branches and Agencies throughout the World

The Welte Mignon Studios offer you ... The Welte Mignon Studios Offer you exceptional opportunities The Welte Mignon Studios The Sun and New York Herald New York 1920 The Sun and New York Herald Friday, April 30, 1920 5 English
The Welte Mignon Studios Offer you exceptional opportunities
The Master Himself
Not just mechanical playing of his compositions,but his own fingers on your keyboard.
At Your Command
Accept as soon as you can our cordial invita- tion to spend a delightful hour or two with the masters of classic or popular music at our beautiful studios. We shall gladly play your fav- orite selections. We shall place at your disposal the services of a staff of musicians whose advice is al- ways ready but is never intruded. We offer a re- markable collection of instruments at reasonable prices and on exceptional terms.
If Paderewski played to you, on your own piano, ex- actly as he played at the very zenith of his career when those marvelous fingers performed miracles, you could count it a great event in your life. This is what the WELTE MIGNON Reproducing Piano will do for you. Paderewski played his soul into the Welte , knowingfull well that thus could he better pass on to coming gen-erations the perfect expression of his genius. It is the soul-expression that you feel when you listen to the Welte ; and you may hear it not only once, but as often as you wish. Paderewski, Lhevinne, Hofmann, de Pachman, Busoni, Saint-Saens, Grieg, d'Albert–156 masters in all have played into the Welte for you the very essence of their musical personalities , for Welte re- production is not "stencil cutting," but absolute tonal duplication. There are over 5,000 record-rolls in the Welte repertoire. Come in to-day and hear your favorites. And bear in mind that the Welte is within your means, for it is sold on terms–your own within reason.
Our stock includes many examples of fine standard makes– Welte, Estey, Conway, and others–shown in a variety of case-designs and woods, giving you ample op- portunity to find the instrument that exactly suits your taste and means. We sell all grades (except "cheap"). You can buy from us a really good instrument as low as $450 , on a series of monthly payments–terms, your own within reason.
Pianos and Player-Pianos at the Prices You expect to Pay
WELTE TERMS
We maintain that if music is to be enjoyed by everyone, it must be with in everyone's reach. So we placed every instrument in the Welte Mignon Studios just there–within EVERYONE'S means. Pick out any instrument you like, from lowest to highest price, and buy it on terms that are practically your own.
A wonderful showing of Phonographs
VICTROLAS
Advertises Victor products and models.
Advertises Pathe products and models
PATHE
Advertises Victor Records and Pathe discs.
Can you drop in at once? No matter how many times you've visited the Studios before this, come in again; there's always something new to see and to hear. Re- member that you are never pressed to buy–just come in as you would visit a famous picture gallery. But if you cannot come today or to- morrow; at least, send this coupon by way of getting information on the latest instrument designs.
RECORDS

Felix Mottl Max Reger Richard Strauss
Das Welte Mignon ist eine unbedingt geniale Erfindung , und hat einen hohen künstlerischen Wert. Ich habe selten eine so schöne und freudige Ueberraschung erlebt, wie heute, wo ich dieses prächtige Instrument kennengelernt habe. Felix Mottl. Mignon ist für mich das unerreichte Ideal aller Musik-Instrumente , eine Erfindung von unschätz- barer Bedeutung für Lehrer, Schüler , Publikum und alle Künstler. Max Reger. Das Welte Mignon ist eine ganz ausserordentliche Erfindung, von allen derartigen Mechanismen der Einzige, der auf künstlerische Bedeutung Anspruch machen kann. Den Erfindern meine aufrichte Bewunderung. Richard Strauss
Mit dem Welte Mignon ist, wie die berühmtesten Künstler anerkennen, ein phantastisch scheinender Gedanke verwirklicht, nämlich das Klavierspiel eines Künstlers mit all seinen persönlichen Eigenschaften - des Anschlags, der Phrasierung, des Pedalgebrauchs, etc. zu verewigen . Die Wiedergaben des Mignon haben jeden Rest des mecha- nischen verlassen. Dass es sich um eine Erfindung von ausserordentlicher künstlerischer Bedeutung handelt, beweist ihr Gebrauch im K. K. Konservatorium in Wien zu Studienzwecken . Der Besitzer eines Welte Mignon kann sich jederzeit von den berühmtesten Musikern, wie d'Albert Carreno, Lamond, Mottl, Reger, Strauss, Paderewsky etc. vorspielen lassen.

Ein musikalisches Weltwunder Ein musikalisches Weltwunder Alfred Schmid Nachf. Allgemeine Zeitung München 1905 Allgemeine Zeitung 27.12.1905 4 Bayerische Staatsbibliothek https://www.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/view/bsb00085796_01057_u001?page=4 German
Ein musikalisches Weltwunder.
Deutschem Erfindungsgeist ist es geglückt, eine geradezu phantastisch er- scheinende Idee - ein akustisches Seitenstück zur Platte des Photo-graphen - zu verwirklichen. Die neue Erfindung ist das Reproduktionsklavier "Mignon", welches das Spiel der berühmten Meister des Klavierspiels selbsstätig und völlig getreu wiedergibt. Das Reproduktionsklavier hat nichts gemein mit mechanischen Spielapparaten wie Pianola, Phonola etc., sondern es hört die Unterscheidung zwischen dem Spiel des aufgenommenen Künstlers und der Wiedergabe des Reproduktionsklaviers überhaupt auf. Ueber die blosse Finger- fertigkeit vermag dieses Wunderklavier alles, was an der Leistung eines Künst- lers das Persönliche und Charakteristische ausmacht, zur Geltung zu bringen; es handelt sich also nicht um ein Surrogat, sondern um eine vollwertige Vertretung. Wer mit der Spielweise d'Alberts, Lamonds, Rislers, Staven-hagens etc. vertraut ist, vermag sie bei der Wiedergabe sofort zu erkennen. Wenn das Reproduktionsklavier vor 50 Jahren existiert hätte, könnten wirauch heute noch dem Spiel der grossen Meister wie Liszt, Rubinstein, Bülowlauschen und daran lernen . Von den Grossen der Gegenwart ist das Spielaber nun für die Nachwelt festgehalten; schon jetzt sind zur Reproduktinaufgenommen: Eugen d'Albert, Konrad Ansorge, Ferruccio Busoni, TeresaCarreno, Ernst von Dohnányi, Artur Friedheim, Ossip Gabrilowitsch, AlfredGrünfeld, Heinrich Grünfeld, Clotilde Kleeberg, Alexander Krah, FredericLamond, Artur Nikisch, Egon Petri, Raoul Pugno, Max Reger, Carl Reinecke, Alfred Reisenauer, Alice Ripper, Xaver Scharwenka, Artur Schnabel, JosephSlivinski, Bernhard Stavenhagen, Felix Weingartner, Karl Wendling. DasReproduktionsklavier bedeutet für die Hausmusik eine unendliche Bereiche-rung. Nicht nur, dass man in seinem Heim sich jeden Augenblick von denobengenannten Künstlern vorspielen lassen kann , wer singt oder geigt etc. wird sich sogar künstlerisch vollendet begleiten lassen können. Die Bedeutung der Erfindung in denn auch von allen namhaften Pianisten anerkannt worden, wie nachfolgende Aeusserungen beweisen:
Eugen d'Albert: Das Mignon-Reproduktionsklavier ist eine Aufsehen erregende Erfindung. Konrad Ansorge: Es ist ein ausgezeichnetes Bildungs- mittel für Konservatorien, wo den Stu- dierenden die Vortragsart eines Mei- sters zu jeder Zeit vorgeführt werden kann. Ferruccio Busoni: Mignon ist ebenso verblüffend für den Eingeweihten, als sie für den Einge- weihten bewunderungswürdig sein muss. Teresa Carreno: Meine Bewunderung für die grossartige Erfindung kennt keine Grenzen. Ernst von Dohnányi: Man kann nur staunen und bewundern. Ossip Gabrilowitsch: Mignon ist sicher eine der wunder- barsten Erfindungen, die dem mensch- lichen Geiste gelungen sind. Alfred Grünfeld: Ich gestehe gerne, dass ich geradezu verblüfft war, als ich mit eigenen Ohren hörte, in welcher Weise Mignon die von Künstlerhand gespielten Musik- stücke wiedergibt.
Verführung des Klaviers kann einstweilen nur nach vorhergegangener Anmeldung erfolgen. Alleinvertretung bei Alfred Schmid Nachf.,
33-34 Theatinerstrasse 33-34.
Clotilde Kleeberg: Es scheint mir, als ob in Mignon der Spie-gel der Musikseele gefunden wäre . Frederic Lamond: Ich sehe den Mignon-Apparat als dasgrösste Wunder der Jetztzeit an . Artur Nikisch: Die Wiedergabe ist nach jeder Richtung, sowohl was das rein technisch virtuose, als auch was das musikalisch-poetische Moment betrifft, eine so verblüffend natürliche, dassman wirklich meint, den Künstler in Person vor sich zu sehen und ihn spielen zu hören. Raoul Pugno: In dieser Wiedergabe findet man alle charakteristischen Eigenschaften des Künst- lers, den Rhythmus, die Eleganz und Vir- tuosität im Spiel, seine Auffassung in Be- zug auf die Phrasierung und sogar die Verwendung der beiden Pedale. Alfred Reisenauer: Hier ist zugleich ein technisches und philo- sophisches Problem in vollendetster Form gelöst. Felix Weingartner: Der Mignon-Apparat ist das Unglaublichste an Vollendung, was man sich denken kann. Was grosse Meister unserer Tage leisten, kann nun nicht mehr untergehen und spä- tere Genarationen werden die Früchte die- ser genialen Erfindung genissen.

Ein musikalisches Weltwunder Das Reproduktionsklavier Alfred Schmid Nachf. Münchner neueste Nachrichten München 1907 Münchner neueste Nachrichten 14.12.1907 5 German
Das Reproduktions- Klavier
gibt das Spiel der berühmten Meister des Klaviers selbst- tätig und völlig getreu wieder , sodass die Unterscheidung zwischen dem Spiel des Künstlers und der Wiedergabe auf dem Reproduktionsklavier überhaupt aufhört. Ueber die blosse Fingerfertigkeit vermag dieses Wunderklavier alles, was an der Leistung eines Künstlers das Persönliche und Charakteristische ausmacht, zur Geltung zu bringen; es handelt sich also nicht um ein Surrogat, sondern um eine vollwertige Vertretung. Wer mit der Spielweise d'Alberts, Busonis, Lamonds, Stavenhagens etc. vertraut ist, wird bei der Wiedergabe sofort erkennen, welcher dieser Künstler spielt. Es ist deshalb nur eines zu bedauern, dass diese wundervolle Erfindung nicht schon vor 50 und mehr Jahren gemacht worden ist. Dann wäre es möglich, auch heute noch sich an dem Spiel der grossen Meister wie Chopin, Liszt, Rubinstein, Bülow etc. zu erfreuen und davon zu lernen . Von fast allen Grossen der Gegenwart, seien es Pianisten, Komponisten oder Dirigenten, ist das Klavier- spiel nun für die Nachwelt festgehalten. Aus den zahlreichen begeisterten Kundgebungen der massgebendsten Künstler sei nur die Felix Weingartners nachstehend angeführt: "Das Reproduktionsklavier ist das unglaublichste an Vollendung, was man sich denken kann. Was grosse Meister unserer Tage leisten, kann nun nicht mehr untergehen und spätere Generationen werden die Früchte dieser genialen Erfindung geniessen." Die nächste Vorführung des Reproduktionsklaviers findet Sonntag den 15. Dezember nach- mittags 5 Uhr statt, wozu Musikfreunde höflichst eingeladen sind. Pianohaus Alfred Schmid Nachf. Kgl. Bayer. Hofmusikalienhandlung, Hoflieferant Sr. Kgl. Hoheit des Prinzen Rupprecht von Bayern.
34 Theatinerstrasse 34

A really satisfactory way to buy musical instruments
A FEELING of utter confidence is engendered at the Welte Mignon Studios. You instinctively know that your continued patronage is sought and, therefore, that everything will be made to bend toward giving you thorough and complete satisfaction. There is a wide range of instruments from which to choose, at prices and on terms thoroughly in accord with your own idea of what is equitable.
The Welte-Mignon Reproducing Piano The instrument chosen by Paderewski, Lhe-vinne, Hofman , Busoni and scores of others, to preserve their genius for posterity. You should hear Paderewski's reproductions; hear how he has played his soul into indestructible records for the Welte-Mignon . Records which you may reproduce at any time and as often as you like , in your own home. One hundred and fifty-six musicians have recorded more than five thousand selections for the Welte-Mignon. Imagine the delight to be derived from such a collection. And consider that the Welte-Mignon Reproducing Piano is within everyone's means, for it may be bought on your terms, with in reason. Just drop in at the Studios to hear the Welte play. Please feel free to ask for your favorite selections. We consider the pleasure entirely ours.

DESIGN OF OAK CASE
THE Welte-Mignon Brings to your home the actual living perform- ances of Hofmann, Lhevinne, Paderewski, Bloomfield-Zeisler and a hundred other great pianists.

The science of musical reproduction has progressed through the various stages-experiment, medioc- rity, excellence-but until the introduction of the Welte-Mignon it has never reached supreme per- fection. But today the science has reached its apex, the goal has been attained and beyond the splendid achievement realized in the Welte-Mignon it is im- possible to go.

The Welte-Mignon brings to the music-lover the actual performances of every great living pian- ist. It perpetuates these performances so that fu- ture generations will enjoy the music of our present-day virtuosos when their personalities are but misty memories.

What the Victor is doing for the famous singers of the world the Welte-Mignon is accomplishing for the pianists. But with this difference: The Victor registers the voice vibrations on the disc, whereas the sensitive reproducing devices of the Welte-Mignon are of such nature that every dupli- cate performance IS MADE DIRECTLY ON THE PIANO, thereby reproducing in every detail of touch, tone and technique the actual renditions of the pianists, in every sense their original per- formances.

The series of instruments containing the repro- duction devices are the Welte-Mignon, as illustrated above, the Steinway-Welte, an upright Steinway piano combined with the Welte-Mignon, and the Cabinet-Welte, which may be attached to any grand or upright piano of any make.

Call or Write for Descriptive Literature We will gladly mail to interested parties descriptive literature and prices of the Welte-Mignon instruments. We are especially desirous that you come to our store and give these instruments your personal inspection. FREE RECITALS DAILY FROM 9 A. M. TO 5 P.M-Fourth Floor. Geo J. The Amazing New WELTE-MIGNON Musicalle makes possible for the first time an hour of uninter- rupted music by the great pianists of the world ..
At the touch of a button . . . without moving from your chair . .
TURN BACK the calendar twenty-four years . . . From the House of Welte came the announcement in 1904 of an instrument which exactly reproduced the play- ing of the master pianists. . . . Today–twenty-four years later–the WELTE- MIGNON Corporation announces the second truly great and signifact step in the progress of musical reproduction . . . the WELTE- MIGNON Musicalle. . . . A women relaxes in the soft depths of her favorite chair . . . On the table by her side rests a small tablet with eight ivory but- tons . . . She presses . . . From her superb piano, a WELTE-MIGNON, flow the magic strains of a Chopin Nocturne . . . Paderewski is playing . . . Silence for a mo- ment . . . the silence of appreciation . . . She touches another button, chossing at ran- dom . . . Josef Hofmann-playing Medels- sohn's "Rondo Capriccioso." In modern mood she turns to Gershwin . . . "The Rhap- sody in Blue" . . . For an hour or more, she revels in the worlds great piano music . . . never moving from her chair . . . . This is the new WELTE-MIGNON Musicalle . . . . . . .
Such simplicity operation has never before been achieved in musical reproduction. Every annoying interruption is banished . . . no dials to turn . . . no rerolling . . . no changing of records. The Musicalle is a cabinet containing eight records and the silent mechanism for control- ling them. It is connected with the piano by a small, easily concealed cable. A tablet, scarcely larger than a small book of verse, operates the Musicalle-resting inconspicuously on a table or stand in your library . . . your music room . . . your dining room . . . wherever you wish. Of course, there will be times when you yourself desire to play. Remember that the Musicalle leaves your piano wholly at your disposal-unaffected in appearance, action or tone. The Musicalle together with Welte-Mignon Reproducing Mechanism installed in other makes of Grand Pianos. Prices on request.

Welte's Orchestrion
Michael Welte The Clockmaker of Freiburg
To Michael Welte, the chiming clock- maker of a dreamy hamlet in Germany, belongs the distinction of conceiving and build- ing an instrument that would reproduce the actual playing of a great pianist. Though a clock-maker by trade, Welte was given to study and invention and being called on to design a musical chime for a
clock, he conceived the idea of having the chimes play a tune. On the accuracy and novelty of his chim- ing clocks, Michael Welte, in 1832, found the firm of M. Welte & Sons, a venerable in- stitution now located at Freiburg, Germany. The years elapsed and Welte's clocks chimed the passage of the hours from man- tles in every nook of Europe, while the firm that had begun so humbly had acquired a continental prestige.
In 1849, after three years of patient toil, Michael Welte brought fourth his first Orches- trion, the clumsy forerunner of the marvelous Philharmonic Organs of the present day. "It was a wonder of mechanical perfection, con- taining eleven hundred pipes, that were brought to playing by thousands of small pins, representing the harmonies and melo- dies of musical compositions thus 'written' on three large wooden cylinders, that moved with a startling precision as had been thought impossible before." Many years before Edison dreamed his thrilling dream of the phonograph the fame of Welte's new invention had traveled through all Europe and soon the business of chiming clocks gave way to the making of mechanically operated musical instruments. Dukes and statesmen, musicians of low rank and high rank, came from afar to listen and marvel at Michael Welte's astounding crea- tion. The firm expanded and the business of M. Welte & Sons attained large proportions. In 1865, Emil Welte, a son of the founder,
Welte's Wonder Invention
came to America where success was instan- taneous. The demand for Welte's Orches- trions, coming now from two hemispheres, led, in 1872, to the removal to Freiburg, which thus became the musical shrine of Europe. Eight years later Michael Welte, the clock- maker closed his eyes forever, leaving his sons endowed with his own inventive genius In 1887, Emil Welte startled the world by the invention of a paper music-roll in connection with a pneumatic action, thus eliminating the bulky wooden cylinders and giving the instrument an unlimited repertoire.

Welte's Dream of Living Music -- A Reality

It was only natural that the artistic develop- ment of Welte Orchestrions and Philhar- monic Organs should have led the thoughts of the Weltes onward and upward to the idea of recording the playing of the musician and applying to the piano a new principle -that of reproducing the artist's playng by means of an automatic instrument. Thus was conceived Welte-Mignon* (pro- nounce Well-tee Mee-yon) or "Little Welte," as it was designated to distinguish it from the large instruments on which
the Welte reputation and business had been established. Thus M. Welte & Sons were origina- tors of the idea of reproducing the playing of pianists, and were granted the original, basic patents on reproducing mechanisms now em- ployed in the Welte-Mignon* Reproducing Action manufactured by the Auto Pneumatic Action Company, under a license granting the unrestricted use of these patents in manu- facturing reproducing actions for the piano industry.
Perfect Reproducing – The Secret of Welte Mignon
The Welte-Mignon method of recording a player's performance is photographic. Through this secret photographic process - possessed only by Welte-Mignon,* available only to Welte-Mignon* - the artist's play- ing is actually photographed – his tempo, his speaking notes, his dynamics, those subtle things that infuse an artist's very soul into his playing. These photographs show precisely the pres- sure with which the artist strikes the keys, whether ever so lightly-pianissimo-or with
the vigor of fortissimo. And this photo- graphic record is so perfect–so identically the physical impression of the master's per- formance, that he is never called upon to edit or arrange the recording. Thus, editing the recording of a great pianist is not necessary with Welte-Mignon* and only with Welte- Mignon is it not necessary. Herein lies the vast difference between Welte-Mignon* recordings of great pianists and those of all other reproducing mechan- isms.
The World's Greatest Pianists record for Welte-Mignon*
